pages.text: You found a plethora of colorful flowers growing around forests and plains in small patches. What's up with those? Definitely worth a look if you haven't tinkered with them already.

pages.title: Crushing Petals
pages.text: While crushing flowers seems a bit unorthodox, it $(italic)did$() work. No problem plucking the petals from the flattened blossom after that.

pages.title: Ink from Petals
pages.text: Having studied not only botany but also color theory, you definitely recognize some similarities. The colored flowers, resemble $(l:general/colored_trees)Colored Trees$(/l) in more than just one point.$(br2)No wonder that their petals can also be used to create $(l:magic/ink)Ink$(/l).

pages.title: Glimmering Flowers
pages.text: Adding some $(l:resources/shimmerstone)Shimmerstone$(/l) to magical flowers makes them glimmer.

pages.title: Colored Mushrooms
pages.text: Applying $(l:general/pigment)Pigment$(/l) to mushrooms colors them in the respective color.
Using $(l:general/pigment)Pigment$(/l) instead of mundane Dye when creating $(item)Floral Fertilizer$() is quite a bit more yielding.
The $(item)Black Lotus$() is a great source of Mana, no questions asked. But yet, it still can be enhanced. Using some $(thing)Jade Petals$()
Those elusive seeds you could only find in chests hidden around the world? Pricey - maybe not even worth the hassle - but you finally found a way to replicate them.

pages.title: Enchanted Soil
pages.text: Enchanted Soil can be harvested using tools enchanted with $(l:enchanting/resonance)Resonance$(/l).

pages.title: New Potion Reagent
pages.text: $(li)+2 positive effects$(li)+1 negative effect$(li)makes the potion unidentifiable.$(br2)$(italic)Fancy a gamble?
